name: Diabetic Macular Edema (DME)
oct:
Core OCT assessment (DME):
• Center involvement: foveal IRF and/or central thickening.
• Pattern: focal vs diffuse; note SRF if present.
• Prognosis markers: DRIL, EZ/ELM disruption, hyperreflective foci, exudate shadowing.
• Check traction (ERM/VMT): if present, medical response may be limited.

Minimum documentation:
• CST/central thickness trend
• IRF/SRF present? (Yes/No)
• EZ status (intact/patchy/broken)
octa:
OCT-A (helpful when available):
• FAZ enlargement/irregularity → ischemic maculopathy risk.
• SCP/DCP dropout (DCP often earlier).
Artifact checks: motion, projection, segmentation errors.

Use OCT‑A especially when vision is worse than OCT edema suggests or response is poor.
targets:
Decision outputs:
1) Center‑involving DME + vision impact/significant IRF/SRF → Anti‑VEGF pathway (often monthly x3 then extend/PRN).
2) Tractional component (ERM/VMT) → retina opinion.
3) Inadequate response after adequate anti‑VEGF trial → consider steroid pathway (esp pseudophakic), per retina plan.
4) Optimize systemic factors: HbA1c, BP, lipids, renal status.
red_flags:
Red flags:
• Large FAZ enlargement/marked DCP dropout with poor vision (ischemic maculopathy).
• Tractional DME (ERM/VMT) with distortion.
• New NVE/NVD suspicion; vitreous hemorrhage symptoms.
• Mimics: recent surgery (CME), uveitis, RVO, CSC (SRF‑dominant).
follow_up:
Follow-up:
• Active treatment/induction: 4–6 weeks.
• After stability: 6–10 weeks (treat‑and‑extend/PRN per retina protocol).
Track each visit: CST trend + IRF/SRF + DRIL/EZ; monitor IOP if steroids used.
triage:
Triage:
• Treat now: CI‑DME with ↓vision or clearly significant IRF/SRF.
• Refer retina early if tractional signs or suspected ischemic maculopathy.
Urgent if: rapid vision drop, new hemorrhage symptoms, suspected NVE/NVD.

name: Wet AMD / CNV (Active)
oct:
OCT essentials (active CNV / wet AMD):
• SRF and/or IRF.
• PED (serous or fibrovascular; irregular elevation suggests activity).
• SHRM suggests active CNV.
• EZ disruption = prognosis marker.

Document: SRF/IRF (Y/N), PED type, SHRM (Y/N), EZ status.
octa:
OCT-A (recommended when available):
• Identify CNV network; confirm correct slabs/segmentation.
• Helps confirm CNV when OCT subtle and track persistence when fluid is minimal.
targets:
Decision outputs:
• Any convincing exudation (SRF/IRF/SHRM/PED with symptoms) → anti‑VEGF pathway (retina).
• Consider masqueraders in atypical cases: CSC/vitelliform/myopic CNV (use history + OCT patterns).
red_flags:
Red flags:
• Increasing SRF/IRF/SHRM or rising PED height.
• New symptoms: distortion, central scotoma, rapid acuity drop.
• Masqueraders: CSC/vitelliform—recheck history and OCT features.
follow_up:
Follow-up:
• Induction: 4–6 weeks (monthly loading) then treat‑and‑extend based on OCT dryness.
• Sudden distortion/vision drop/new scotoma → urgent review.
triage:
Triage:
• Treat/Refer urgently if SRF/IRF/SHRM or suspicious PED with symptoms.
• If SRF‑dominant + CSC context → consider CSC DDx before labeling wet AMD.

name: Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO)
oct:
OCT pattern (BRVO):
• Sectoral macular edema/thickening; cystoid IRF often in INL/OPL.
• Exudates/hemorrhage may cause shadowing; outer retina often relatively preserved early.
• Check vitreomacular interface (ERM/VMT) – can sustain edema.

Document: IRF/SRF (Y/N), CST trend, EZ integrity, VMI traction (Y/N).
octa:
OCT-A (ischemia support):
• FAZ enlargement/irregularity.
• Capillary dropout/non-perfusion (DCP often most affected).
Before calling ischemia, exclude artifacts: motion lines, projection, segmentation errors.
targets: Key goals: treat edema, assess ischemia risk, monitor for neovascular complications.
red_flags:
Red flags:
• Rapid vision loss, massive edema/SRF (think ischemic CRVO).
• Extensive OCT‑A dropout / large FAZ; suspected NVE/NVD.
• Poor/atypical response → reconsider diagnosis (DME/uveitis/CME).
follow_up:
Follow-up:
• Acute phase: 4–6 weeks (or per injection schedule).
• If ischemic features/large dropout: 2–4 weeks per retina plan.
• Stable chronic: 8–12 weeks.
triage:
Triage:
• Vision‑limiting macular edema → retina/anti‑VEGF pathway (early treatment improves outcomes).
• Suspected ischemic event (large dropout/very poor vision) → urgent retina referral (high NV risk).
• Mild edema + good vision → observe with close follow‑up (still counsel red flags).

name: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO)
oct:
OCT pattern (CRVO):
• Diffuse macular edema; very high CST common.
• SRF is common; IRF often extensive.
• EZ disruption/DRIL can appear early → prognosis marker.
• Check VMI (ERM/VMT).

Document: IRF/SRF, CST trend, EZ status, VMI traction.
octa:
OCT-A (ischemia support):
• FAZ enlargement/irregularity.
• Capillary dropout/non-perfusion (DCP often most affected).
Before calling ischemia, exclude artifacts: motion lines, projection, segmentation errors.
targets: Key goals: treat edema, identify ischemic CRVO, monitor for NV complications.
red_flags:
Red flags:
• Rapid vision loss, massive edema/SRF (think ischemic CRVO).
• Extensive OCT‑A dropout / large FAZ; suspected NVE/NVD.
• Poor/atypical response → reconsider diagnosis (DME/uveitis/CME).
follow_up:
Follow-up:
• Acute phase: 4–6 weeks (or per injection schedule).
• If ischemic features/large dropout: 2–4 weeks per retina plan.
• Stable chronic: 8–12 weeks.
triage:
Triage:
• Vision‑limiting macular edema → retina/anti‑VEGF pathway (early treatment improves outcomes).
• Suspected ischemic event (large dropout/very poor vision) → urgent retina referral (high NV risk).
• Mild edema + good vision → observe with close follow‑up (still counsel red flags).

ddx_rules.reason: Severe ischemia with carotid/vascular risk context

name: Epiretinal Membrane (ERM)
oct: Retinal wrinkling / loss of foveal pit

name: Vitreomacular Traction (VMT)
oct: Posterior hyaloid face attached to fovea

name: Hydroxychloroquine Toxicity
oct: Flying Saucer Sign (loss of ellipsoid zone)

name: Angioid Streaks
targets: Watch for CNV growth through breaks

name: Ocular Ischemic Syndrome
targets: Arterial transit time delay (if video available)

name: TB-Associated Serpiginous-like Choroiditis
oct: Look for outer retinal/RPE disruption and sub-RPE changes
octa: Look for CC flow void corresponding to active lesion
targets: Outer retina slab for secondary CNV
RPE/outer retina integrity on structural OCT

name: VKH (Acute serous detachments / choroiditis)
oct: Look for multilobular SRF, septae, RPE folds
Check choroidal thickening (if enhanced depth available)
octa: Look for diffuse CC hypoperfusion/flow voids
targets: SRF pattern documentation for response to therapy

name: CMV Retinitis (immunocompromised)
oct: Look for full-thickness retinal hyperreflectivity and disruption
octa: Slabs: SCP/DCP (capillary dropout can be extensive)
Use mainly for documentation, not diagnosis

name: Toxoplasma Retinochoroiditis (active vs scar)
oct: Look for focal full-thickness hyperreflectivity, vitreous cells shadowing
octa: Slabs: CC + Outer retina (exclude CNV in scars)
targets: Exclude CNV in old scar if new symptoms

name: Eales Disease / Peripheral Vasculitis (screen)
oct: Macula cube (often normal unless edema/ERM present)
If VA drop → look for CME or vitreomacular traction
octa: Macular OCT-A may miss peripheral disease
If using: 6×6 mm SCP/DCP to document ischemia signs
Use mainly for macular ischemia/CME correlation

name: PCV / Aneurysmal Type 1 Neovascularization (common in Asians)
oct: Macula cube + line scans through PED
Look for sharp-peaked PED, notches, sub-RPE changes, SRF
octa: Look for branching vascular network; polyps may be variable on OCTA

name: Macular Telangiectasia Type 2
oct: Look for inner/outer lamellar cavities, ILM drape, EZ disruption temporal
octa: Slabs: SCP + DCP (telangiectatic changes often in DCP)
Check right-left asymmetry and parafoveal vascular changes

name: PAMM / AMN (acute ischemic maculopathy patterns)
oct: High-res line scan through symptomatic area
AMN: outer plexiform/outer retina focal lesions
octa: Look for focal DCP flow deficits

name: Glaucoma Suspect / RNFL-GCC Protocol
oct: ONH/RNFL scan (peripapillary circle) + optic disc cube
octa: Document radial peripapillary capillary density (adjunct, not primary)

name: Papilledema / Disc Edema (screen + follow-up)
oct:
OCT (ONH/RNFL) documentation:
• RNFL thickness: diffuse swelling typical; note asymmetry/quadrants.
• ONH contour: elevated disc; peripapillary subretinal hyporeflective space may be present.
• Beware segmentation errors in high swelling.

Key: OCT supports diagnosis/monitoring but does NOT replace systemic evaluation.
octa:
OCT-A (optional):
• Peripapillary perfusion changes are variable and not primary for diagnosis.
Clinical pathway + systemic workup remain decisive.
targets:
Decision outputs:
• Suspected papilledema clinically → urgent neuro‑ophthalmology/neurology pathway.
• Use OCT to document baseline RNFL/ONH and monitor response after treatment begins.
red_flags:
Red flags:
• Rapid symptom progression or vision drop.
• Marked asymmetry (consider alternate diagnoses).
• Pseudopapilledema possibility (disc drusen) if chronic/asymptomatic—confirm with appropriate tests if available.
follow_up:
Follow-up:
• Arrange urgent systemic evaluation first.
• Repeat OCT in 2–6 weeks to document response once treatment starts.
• RNFL may later thin after resolution—interpret trend with symptoms.
triage:
Triage (high-stakes):
Urgent escalation if any of:
• headache + vomiting
• transient visual obscurations
• diplopia
• pulsatile tinnitus
• rapid vision change
Do not “watch and wait” if raised ICP suspected.

name: NAION / Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (supportive OCT)
oct: Later follow-up shows sectoral RNFL thinning
octa: Optional: ONH OCT-A to document perfusion reduction
red_flags: GCA suspicion symptoms (older patients) → urgent referral
